These

These (aliased as \&/) is an inclusive “or” of two data types, as opposed to \/, which is an exclusive “or”. These[A, B] is isomorphic to A \/ B \/ (A, B), but is significantly easier to use and has different typeclass instances.

import scalaz._
import Scalaz._

Basics

A value of type A \&/ B can be constructed in one of three ways:

scala> type IntAndOrString = Int \&/ String
defined type alias IntAndOrString

scala> val anInt: IntAndOrString = This(123)
anInt: IntAndOrString = This(123)

scala> val aString: IntAndOrString = That("a")
aString: IntAndOrString = That(a)

scala> val both: IntAndOrString = Both(456, "bcd")
both: IntAndOrString = Both(456,bcd)

and destructured by pattern matching:

scala> (anInt, aString, both) match {
     |   case (This(int1), That(str1), Both(int2, str2)) => (int1, str1, int2, str2)
     |   case _ => ???
     | }
res0: (Int, String, Int, String) = (123,a,456,bcd)

There is also a fold method which is equivalent to pattern matching:

scala> def myFold(t: IntAndOrString) = t.fold(_ => "This")(_ => "That")((_, _) => "Both")
myFold: (t: IntAndOrString)String

scala> (myFold(anInt), myFold(aString), myFold(both))
res1: (String, String, String) = (This,That,Both)

Instances

Bifunctor

These is a functor in both of its type parameters:

scala> (anInt.lmap(_ + 1), aString.lmap(_ + 1), both.lmap(_ + 1))
res2: (scalaz.data.These[Int,String], scalaz.data.These[Int,String], scalaz.data.These[Int,String]) = (This(124),That(a),Both(457,bcd))

scala> (anInt.rmap(_ + "-ish"), aString.rmap(_ + "-ish"), both.rmap(_ + "-ish"))
res3: (scalaz.data.These[Int,String], scalaz.data.These[Int,String], scalaz.data.These[Int,String]) = (This(123),That(a-ish),Both(456,bcd-ish))

Its Functor instance maps on the right:

scala> both.map(_ + " and others")
res4: Int \&/ String = Both(456,bcd and others)

Monad

These is a monad if A is a Semigroup. pure is That, and flatMap collects A values in This or Both cases using the semigroupal append.

scala> implicit val intSemigroup: Semigroup[Int] = _ + _
intSemigroup: scalaz.Scalaz.Semigroup[Int] = $$Lambda$4698/217974384@2e340ea9

scala> both.flatMap((s: String) => Both(789, s + s))
res5: scalaz.data.These[Int,String] = Both(1245,bcdbcd)

scala> aString.flatMap(_ => anInt)
res6: scalaz.data.These[Int,String] = This(123)

Semigroup

These is a Semigroup if both A and B are.

scala> anInt append aString
res7: scalaz.data.These[Int,String] = Both(123,a)

scala> anInt append anInt
res8: scalaz.data.These[Int,String] = This(246)

scala> both append anInt
res9: scalaz.data.These[Int,String] = Both(579,bcd)

scala> both append both
res10: scalaz.data.These[Int,String] = Both(912,bcdbcd)

Values can also be appended on either side:

scala> anInt lappend 2
res11: scalaz.data.These[Int,String] = This(125)

scala> aString rappend ", fool"
res12: scalaz.data.These[Int,String] = That(a, fool)

scala> both lappend 1000
res13: scalaz.data.These[Int,String] = Both(1456,bcd)

Other functions:

swap swaps This and That (and therefore also swaps the type arguments):

scala> anInt.swap
res14: scalaz.data.These[String,Int] = That(123)

scala> both.swap
res15: scalaz.data.These[String,Int] = Both(bcd,456)

thisSide and thatSide extract a value from either side as well as Both:

scala> anInt.thisSide
res16: scalaz.data.Maybe[Int] = Some(123)

scala> anInt.thatSide
res17: scalaz.data.Maybe[String] = None

scala> both.thisSide
res18: scalaz.data.Maybe[Int] = Some(456)
